awd_titl_txt: IRES: Multidisciplinary Water Engineering Research and Education to Protect and Enhance Ecosystems in Complex Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This IRES program will offer water engineering research experiences to civil and environmental engineering students who are making the transition from undergraduate-to-graduate study.  Participants will conduct research within one of the leading water engineering units in the world, in some of the finest labs globally, and within extremely complex environments. They will tackle one of three environmental fluid mechanics project areas using field measurements, physical modeling, and numerical methods: 1) Coastal hazard mitigation ecosystem services; 2) Contaminant remediation; and 3) River bed destruction.  Each of these areas connect to ongoing research at the University of Queensland sponsored by major government, nonprofit, and industry agencies.  

As the strain on water resources and ecosystems intensifies, it is becoming increasingly important to educate engineers to be ready to face complex issues related to water monitoring and management that stretch across national boundaries.  The field of water engineering requires a broader educational approach beyond traditional curricula, as today's water engineers face challenging and interdisciplinary issues that combine concepts and methods beyond existing theories and data and instead require a research focus.  In addition to the water engineering research component, this IRES program will make important contributions to water engineering education more broadly, as it will produce research focused on how to enhance the education of water engineers and how and why students develop in these kinds of international research experiences.

por.por_cntn:
This IRES program offered water engineering research experiences to civil and environmental engineering undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Queensland in Australia. Participants conducted research within one of the leading water engineering units in the world, in some of the finest labs globally, and within extremely complex environments. Select examples of project topics included research focused on sediment transport, groundwater contamination, scour processes around dams, coastal processes, sediment transport in rivers, methane emissions from a lake system, and using drone aerial imagery as a means for conducting surveys in coastal environments. These student projects included lab-based research, field-based research, and research that relied on numerical modeling. A highlight of the program included a 27-day fully IRES-student led field experiment on North Stradbroke Island that captured two retrogressive breach failures.

This IRES program also offered opportunities for multiple engineering education graduate students to gain evaluation experience and lead engineering education research in an international environment. These graduate students conducted studies of curriculum and assessment within the Australian undergraduate engineering context, cross-national comparative analyses of engineering education research between the United States and Australia, and studies seeking to understand how and why students develop different skills in these kinds of international research experiences. For example, research explored narratives of researcher development for IRES participants across two of the cohorts and identified critical incidents and themes to characterize the early stage of the researcher development process. Findings demonstrated that students navigated their fit within the research environment in different ways. We recommend that the design of research programs should intentionally consider different levels of the environment and ensure sufficient challenges and supports so that students can assess their fit with research as a career.

In total, the project supported 15 international student experiences that enabled a range of training and professional development for undergraduate and graduate students. Several students have progressed into graduate programs with multiple participants embarking on PhDs, a previously unforeseen outcome which students attributed to their IRES experience. One of the students was awarded a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship, and the IRES experience was a critical element in the review of that proposal. Two of the engineering education PhD students involved in the program attained tenure-track faculty positions, with continued plans to pursue research on students? international research experiences. Moreover, the project indirectly enabled multiple exchanges (e.g., visits and seminars) between the University of Queensland and Virginia Tech faculty and graduate students.

Another element of this project, supported by a supplement received in September 2019, was a case study investigation of nine IRES programs to assess the impact of IRES on researchers and research outcomes. This study has resulted in research that has broader impacts for programs like IRES, PIRE, and REU. Case studies included interviews with U.S. PIs, a selection of additional international and U.S. faculty researchers, and student alumni for a total of 59 interviews. Select findings of this case study include the following:

  • The structure of an IRES program appears to influence the magnitude, scope, and kinds of impacts of the program on faculty members and the institution. Faculty PIs leading the endeavor on their own tended to realize greater individual and research benefits. Although there is a greater logistical demand on an individual faculty member, this model could support their career trajectory. Programs that bring together multiple departments in a network might be a better approach for colleges seeking to achieve broader internationalization. Network-wide programs taking advantage of consortia of institutions collaborating around a common research area could be a better model for graduate students because it becomes easier for students to find a suitable international project aligned with their program of study. 
  • IRES participants cited different program elements that were meaningful and pointed to a variety of learning outcomes, but every student participant said they would recommend similar experiences to others. We identified a variety of program elements that students described affecting their experience (e.g., project structure, mentoring strategy, housing choices). Although we do not recommend a single model, our analyses highlighted considerations ranging from student selection, to orientations and schedules, to the ways in which students? research experiences may be structured. Students also pointed to a variety of different learning outcomes achieved during IRES, including technical and research skill development and cross-cultural and global engineering skills and awareness. By far the most common type of outcomes discussed across all programs related to students? careers or future lives, which included graduate school, industry, further international work and travel, preparation for academia, and building professional networks.

Project findings have been disseminated via several journal articles, conference proceedings, and workshops. A summary report and webinar series that can assist members of the community who are developing new IRES proposals can be accessed at the following site: https://global.eng.vt.edu/Resources/IRES.html.
